instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP1V05_SO: What is PP1V05_SO? This is a typo of PP1V05_S0 When you see PP1V05_SO, assume they meant to type PP1V05_S0.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittant Fan Spin
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with Intermittant Fan Spin (no Liquid Damage)

PP3V42 - 3.47V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> -12.58 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.0 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 5V then off, 5V then off
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.3V then off, 3.3V then off

I tried new clock chip, same result.  Any ideas?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittant Fan Spin
threads.message: CPU Vcore coming on? Liquid damage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittant Fan Spin
threads.message:
No liquid damage.

No CPU VCore

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SO</SIGNAL> are at 5V and 1.05V respectively, but also intermittant  (about 250ms on and 3 sec off)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittant Fan Spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> tries to appear?
Can you catch at least a pulse in that 250ms?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittant Fan Spin
threads.message: Yes, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.2V for 320ms, pulse shows very clean on scope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittant Fan Spin
threads.message: So no voltage pulses at L7510? Check <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> for corrosion. I doubt this "just" happened, what is the history?
